user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_NetworkGetID:
```c
int32 OS_NetworkGetID(void)
{
    int32 IdBuf;

    /* always delegate to low-level API */
    if (OS_NetworkGetID_Impl(&IdBuf) != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /* return a hardcoded value on failure */
        return -1;
    }

    return IdBuf;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_NetworkGetID:
typedef int32_t   int32
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
int32 OS_NetworkGetID_Impl(int32 *IdBuf)
{
    /* gethostid() has no failure modes */
    *IdBuf = gethostid();
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
void UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, size_t ReturnSize, const char *TypeName)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;

    if (ReturnSize > 0)
    {
        /* Check for existing buffer and re-use if same size (should be!) */
        StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER);
        if (StubPtr != NULL && StubPtr->Data.Buff.TotalSize != ReturnSize)
        {
            UT_ClearStubEntry(StubPtr);
            StubPtr = NULL;
        }

        if (StubPtr == NULL)
        {
            StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED);
            if (StubPtr == NULL)
            {
                UtAssert_Abort("Cannot set return buffer - UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS too low?");
            }
            else
            {
                StubPtr->FuncKey           = FuncKey;
                StubPtr->EntryType         = UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER;
                StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr = malloc(ReturnSize);
                if (StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr == NULL)
                {
                    UtAssert_Abort("Cannot allocate data buffer - malloc() failed!");
                }
                else
                {
                    memset(StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr, 0, ReturnSize);
                    StubPtr->ModeFlags |= UT_MODEFLAG_ALLOC_BUF;
                }

                StubPtr->Data.Buff.TotalSize = ReturnSize;
            }
        }

        if (StubPtr != NULL)
        {
            StubPtr->Data.Buff.Position       = 0;
            StubPtr->Data.Buff.ContentTypeStr = TypeName;
        }
    }
}
...
void UT_ExecuteBasicHandler(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, const char *FunctionName, UT_HandlerFunc_t DefaultHandler)
{
    /* Check if the test case registered a hook, and use the default if not */
    if (UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_FINAL_HANDLER) == NULL && DefaultHandler != NULL)
    {
        UT_SetHandlerFunction(FuncKey, DefaultHandler, NULL);
    }

    UT_DefaultStubImpl(FunctionName, FuncKey, 0, NULL);
}
...
void *UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, size_t ReturnSize, const char *TypeName)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;
    void *               ReturnPtr;

    ReturnPtr = NULL;
    StubPtr   = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER);

    if (StubPtr == NULL)
    {
        /* This shouldn't happen, it means the stub tried to use a
         * return buffer that does not exist.
         *
         * It is most likely caused by a mismatch/incompatibility between
         * stub and handler.  Aborting now is better than segfaulting later,
         * as the errored call should still be on the stack trace
         */
        UtAssert_Abort("Return buffer invalid");
    }
    else
    {
        ReturnPtr = StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr;

        /*
         * Sanity check on the size and type name.
         *
         * In a generated stub these should always match, but if any patches
         * were done or if a hand-written stub is used, mistakes could be made.
         */
        if (StubPtr->Data.Buff.Position != ReturnSize || strcmp(TypeName, StubPtr->Data.Buff.ContentTypeStr) != 0)
        {
            UtAssert_Failed("Return value mismatch, expected %s(%lu) got %s(%lu)", TypeName, (unsigned long)ReturnSize,
                            StubPtr->Data.Buff.ContentTypeStr, (unsigned long)StubPtr->Data.Buff.Position);
        }
    }

    return ReturnPtr;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no uses of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided code fragments. I checked for common vendor/extension constructs that would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2, including: __attribute__ or other __attribute__((...)) constructs, __asm__ / inline assembly, statement expressions ({ ...; }), GNU typeof/__typeof__, __extension__, nested functions, #pragma GCC/clang-specific pragmas, __builtin_* functions used as language extensions, and other vendor-specific keywords. The code only uses standard C language constructs and library facilities: typedef of int32_t (from stdint.h), plain function definitions and pointer parameters, standard casts, standard library calls (malloc, memset, strcmp, gethostid), and macros/constants (OS_SUCCESS, UT_MODEFLAG_ALLOC_BUF) that are ordinary identifiers rather than compiler extensions. No fragment in the supplied code indicates a compiler-documented language extension, so nothing needs to be reported for investigation under Rule 1.2.
